conversation.content: [playful] Why are you wearing a full suit to apple picking?
Oh, that's... okay, so here's the thing. The website said "dress for success" and I, um, I misunderstood. I thought it was some kind of corporate team-building event, not actual fruit picking.
You couldn't figure that out from context?

Well, in my defense, the email from HR was really vague, and they're always doing these weird metaphorical exercises. Remember the "synergy salmon swim" last quarter? That turned out to be actual swimming.
That was a pool party, Marcus.
Right, but—but they called it professional development! Look, I realize now that I've made a mistake. These Italian leather shoes are already destroyed, and I think I just got apple juice on my tie.
[very sincerely] Are you having some kind of breakdown?
No, I'm... hmm. Maybe? I've been working seventy-hour weeks for six months, and when I saw "mandatory apple picking," my brain just kind of short-circuited into autopilot corporate mode.
Jesus. When's the last time you actually relaxed?
Define "relaxed." Because if you mean when did I last not check emails for more than two hours, that would be, uh... actually I can't remember. February maybe?
[laugh] You're checking your phone right now, aren't you?
[clearing throat] Just one quick thing—no, you're right. You're absolutely right. I'm putting it away. God, when did I become this person?
The kind who wears Armani to an orchard?

The kind who can't even pick fruit without thinking about quarterly reports. You know what's really pathetic? I actually started calculating the profit margins on these apples while we were walking over here.
That's... deeply concerning.
Yeah, it really is. I used to love this stuff as a kid, you know? Just being outside, getting dirty, not caring about anything except which apple looked the sweetest.
[speeding up] Quick—that family's leaving, grab their ladder before someone else does!
Wait, we're actually doing this? In my suit? I mean... yeah, okay, screw it. You're right. The dry cleaning bill will be worth it if I can remember what fun feels like.
[very melancholic] You really have been miserable lately, haven't you?

Completely. But standing here with you, about to destroy a two-thousand-dollar suit for some apples... this is the first time in months I've felt like myself. The real me, not the spreadsheet version.
